DriverPacks may solve an issue with drivers, but it may also (in some rare cases) introduce it.

The problem is NOT in the MBR (in the sense of the MBR code), and NOT in the setting for the active partition.

As a matter of fact the only thing that a plain XP will look for in the MBR will be:

1. the presence of "Magic Bytes" 55AA
2. the validity of the current partitioning scheme (Partition Table)
3. the presence of a Disk Signature (which must be there, otherwise you wouldn't boot the 7)

As soon as the install actually begins, the XP setup will anyway rewrite from scratch the whole MBR with the exclusion of the three items above and it will set the active parttion to the one where NTLDR is placed.

BTW, this will REPLACE any code you now have in the MBR, may it be the standard Windows 7 one or the GRUB2 one, this means that you need to think before installing the XP if you have the tools and knowledge to re-install (if it is installed to the MBR) the GRUB2.

The point is when/where exactly the issue begins.

Going the CD way, if you get the "press any key to boot form CD" (unless of course you have removed bootfix.bin) is already a sign that the MBR is read (at least the "Magic Bytes" AND one entry in the partition table).

An issue with #3 is to be excluded for the mentioned reasons.

What remains are only:

* issues with the "queer" partitioning scheme (particularly with partition alignments being in "mixed" mode, "canonical CH boundary" vs. "new approach Mb aligned")
* the use of LBA48 not being supported by the setup
* a limit (by design) in the Windows XP setup routine

I will ask these questions again (they were implied in my previous post, but maybe it wasn't clear enough):

1. did you ever install XP on that hard disk to partition sda4?
2. did you ever install XP on that hard disk on any partition starting beyond the 128 GB/LBA48 limit?
3. were all your previous and successful attempts to install XP use as target the first partition?

Among the zillion ways to check a partition table, you could use a hex/disk editor, but maybe easier, get HDhacker:

[http://dimio.altervista.org/eng/](http://dimio.altervista.org/eng/ "External link")

> If i understand correctly Grub2 replaces Windows 7 boot files in MBR sector and on start up it connects to the boot files on Windows 7 partition to boot windows. But Windows 7 boot manager can't boot Ubuntu because it doesn't recognize linux.

Not really-really.

The "normal" boot sequence is:

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>whatever OS loader

i.e.:

DOS:

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>IO.SYS

NT up to 2003:

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>NTLDR-\>BOOT.INI (choices)-\>NTDETECT.COM-\>Windows NT

NT starting from Vista ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>BOOTMGR-\>\\boot\\BCD (choices)-\>Winload.exe-\>Windows NT

I.e. the MBR code is a simple IPL (Initial Program Loader) that simply chainloads the PBR of the active partition, and the PBR code is a simple loader for the actual OS loader.

GRUB (legacy), grub4dos and GRUB2 are more complex.

They can be installed to the MBR (+ a number of hidden sectors on first track) and in this case they "bypass" the above mechanism, the code in the MBR (+hidden sectors) is a loader for the "main" grub file (be it stage2, grldr or core.img) and no code is needed in the PBR.

Or they can be installed to the PBR.

In this case the MBR contains "conventional" IPL code that loads the PBR of the active partition or it can be an "advanced" MBR code, such as partita or OS-MBR that can choose which partition to make active and boot on-the-fly.

Once a bootmanager like the "grub family" is loaded you are inside a "reduced" real mode OS and from that you can load \*almost anything\*.

I am not going to check your setupreg.hiv, not because I am an old grumpy bastard (which I am :wink:) but because since you are wanting to learn about booting matters, you need to do some homework and get familiar with the tools and concepts of this field.

If you need help on how to check it, just ask :smile:.

DriverPacks may solve an issue with drivers, but it may also (in some rare cases) introduce it.

The problem is NOT in the MBR (in the sense of the MBR code), and NOT in the setting for the active partition.

As a matter of fact the only thing that a plain XP will look for in the MBR will be:

1. the presence of "Magic Bytes" 55AA
2. the validity of the current partitioning scheme (Partition Table)
3. the presence of a Disk Signature (which must be there, otherwise you wouldn't boot the 7)

As soon as the install actually begins, the XP setup will anyway rewrite from scratch the whole MBR with the exclusion of the three items above and it will set the active parttion to the one where NTLDR is placed.

An issue with #3 is to be excluded for the mentioned reasons.

* the use of LBA48 not being supported by the setup

> If i understand correctly Grub2 replaces Windows 7 boot files in MBR sector and on start up it connects to the boot files on Windows 7 partition to boot windows. But Windows 7 boot manager can't boot Ubuntu because it doesn't recognize linux.

Not really-really.

The "normal" boot sequence is:

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>whatever OS loader

i.e.:

DOS:

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>IO.SYS

NT up to 2003:

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>NTLDR-\>BOOT.INI (choices)-\>NTDETECT.COM-\>Windows NT

NT starting from Vista ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)

BIOS-\>MBR-\>PBR of active primary partition-\>BOOTMGR-\>\\boot\\BCD (choices)-\>Winload.exe-\>Windows NT

I.e. the MBR code is a simple IPL (Initial Program Loader) that simply chainloads the PBR of the active partition, and the PBR code is a simple loader for the actual OS loader.

GRUB (legacy), grub4dos and GRUB2 are more complex.

They can be installed to the MBR (+ a number of hidden sectors on first track) and in this case they "bypass" the above mechanism, the code in the MBR (+hidden sectors) is a loader for the "main" grub file (be it stage2, grldr or core.img) and no code is needed in the PBR.

Or they can be installed to the PBR.

In this case the MBR contains "conventional" IPL code that loads the PBR of the active partition or it can be an "advanced" MBR code, such as partita or OS-MBR that can choose which partition to make active and boot on-the-fly.

Once a bootmanager like the "grub family" is loaded you are inside a "reduced" real mode OS and from that you can load \*almost anything\*.

I am not going to check your setupreg.hiv, not because I am an old grumpy bastard (which I am :wink:) but because since you are wanting to learn about booting matters, you need to do some homework and get familiar with the tools and concepts of this field.

If you need help on how to check it, just ask :smile:.

> I used **root (hd0,2)** this time and i was able to boot Windows xp. But how to create menu.lst so i can have boot menu with Windows 7 and Windows XP?  

Create a new file with notepad.

Save it as C:\\menu.lst

Type in it (or copy and paste):

```

timeout 30
title Load Windows XP on (hd0,2)
root (hd0,2)
chainloader /ntldr

title Switch to GRUB2 core.img for booting Linux (Ubuntu, etc)
find --set-root --ignore-floppies --ignore-cd /boot/grub/i386-pc/core.img
kernel /boot/grub/i386-pc/core.img

title commandline
commandline

title reboot
reboot
```

The second entry may work for your current Ubuntu install, do check that you have a core.img in /boot/grub/i386-pc/core.img (or change the paths accordingly to where your core.img is).

That entry should chainload the GRUB2 (but you can later decide - as hinted before - to insert the settings for the Ubuntu directly in the menu.lst).

The above is an as-plain-as-possible example of menu.lst, there are tens of possible "advanced" settings, including the use of a "splash image", custom colours, the possibility to have an animated Gfx menu, etc (if you do not like the "plain" look of the above).

> I created the menu.lst file and i was able to boot Windows XP and Ubuntu - for Ubuntu the right path was boot/grub/core.img. But is it possible to put all three entries in the main menu, like Grub2?  
> Also, i have noticed that when my live usb is plugged in, it can't boot Windows XP. It says that (hd0,2) partition doesn't exist.

Yes/No.

Right now your "main" boot manager is the Windows 7 bootmgr.

To have a single menu allowing you to select any of the three (among 7, XP or Ubuntu) you have two "main" ways:

1. make grub4dos your "main" boot manager
2. have two copies of grldr (named differently) each one having an "embedded" menu.lst, one pointing to the XP and one pointing to the Ubuntu (or use - say - menu.lst and mynu.lst as menu files)

When you plug a USB Mass Storage device (it depends on the actual machine/BIOS and how it behaves specifically) disk order may be altered.

The entry you have now for XP is "hardcoded" to (hd0,2), if the first disk (hd0) becomes the USB device of course it will point to tthe "wrong" device.

A way to avoid this is to use a "tag" file.

Open Notepad and save the file as (it can be empty alright) \<whatever letter the XP partition has\>\\myXPdrive.tag

Then change the line:

```

root (hd0,2)
```

to:

```

find --set-root --ignore-floppies --ignore-cd /myXPdrive.tag
```

this way, no matter which disk is the first one, the root will be established to the "right" drive.

BUT, if actually the disk order is altered, then the arcpath entry in the BOOT.INI you have now on the XP partition won't work.

Right now you have something like:
> multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(**0**)partition(2)\\WINDOWS="Microsoft Windows XP Professional" /noexecute=optin /fastdetect
>
which is also "linked" to first disk.

This means that you may need to exchange disks.

This can be done in grub4dos alright, but it begins being "advanced", i.e. you will need to add a minimal "scripting" to your menu.lst.

Try (example, but should work ![:unsure:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)):

```

title XP on *any* device
find --set-root --ignore-floppies --ignore-cd /myXPdrive.tag
set disknum=%@root:~3,1%
if not %disknum%==0 map (hd0) (hd%disknum%) &&map (hd%disknum%) (hd0)
if not %disknum%==0 map --hook
find --set-root --ignore-floppies --ignore-cd /myXPdrive.tag
chainloader /ntldr
```

One general question: What boot loader is better to use as main - Windows 7 bootmgr, grub4dos or Grub2?

I think Grub2 is more easy to use but you seem don't think it's a good boot loader?

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> One general question: What boot loader is better to use as main - Windows 7 bootmgr, grub4dos or Grub2?
>
> I think Grub2 is more easy to use but you seem don't think it's a good boot loader?

Any boot manager (not boot loader) is good within it's limits.

The GRUB2 and grub4dos can be installed BOTH to the MBR or to a PBR/VBR.

I personally find "wrong" to install any of them to the MBR, because they install on the MBR AND on several of the hidden sectors.

Additionally the GRUB2 MBR CODE uses also a few addresses that have been traditionally marked as "reserved" or "not used".

Any number of programs may need/want (outside any "standard" or "good practice") to use those bytes or more likely any of the hidden sectors for their own use.

The result might be that when you use any of these programs, suddenly you cannot boot anymore.

GRUB2 has also - in my opinion - the disadvantage of an overly (unneededly) complex syntax, additionally very scarcely documented and the senseless use of the "core.img" built-on-the-spot, but set aside this, it is an excellent boot manager, though it is in no way "grand", let alone "unified" as it is mainly - I would say uniquely - oriented to Linux.

And ironically it seemingly has (or may be had ![:unsure:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)) issues when installed to ext***n*** PBR/VBR.

grub4dos is much more flexible, has a much plainer syntax, has advanced scripting capabilities, can chainload "directly" (i.e. bypassing th ePBR/VBR almost \*any\* OS), can it be installed to the MBR (not advised by me) to the PBR, loaded form Linux, or from DOS, besides NTLDR and BOOTMGR but has it's own limitations, currently one that is showing is the support for BIOS only (and not EFI/UEFI) machines.

BOOTMGR is 3/4 OS loader (or boot loader) and 1/4 only (say) boot manager, it uses another stupidly complex configuration file and syntax (the \\boot\\BCD) and is rather limited.

NTLDR is also a 3/4 OS loader and 1/4 only (say) boot manager, and it's only advantage is that it uses a very plain format for it's BOOT.INI.

It is just a matter of personal tastes and familiarity with the tools, and there are many more boot managers to choose among, like Syslinux, as an example.

I personally rate the inherent simplicity and flexibiity of grub4dos to be far superior to any of the other mentioned boot managers, but that's just me, of course.
